subject: Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: ... and not ... not be ... just ... Only indefinite vowels sounds before terminal D should be dropped and then only if the -ed is a grammatical ending. Other
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...>
>
> >
> > > How about the "ed" endings? Should these all be changed to "d"?
> >
> > That's trickier. The CMU version of "-ed" is " IH0 D", but you have to
> > also verify that the Orthodox version actually does end in "-ed"
and not
> > "-id" (such as "arachnid"). Furthermore, the preceding letter must
not be
> > "D", or "loaded" will become Low-Owe-Day-Day.
> >
>
> That's easy to do, because I convert the CMU dictionary to QS. So I
just
> need to change endings with an "ed." (Though what about the word Ed and
> others like it?) As far as a double Deed character, that seems to be
> what you are supposed to do, so far as I can tell--at least that is how
> I have seen such words.
>
> Paul
>


Only indefinite vowels sounds before terminal D should be dropped and
then only if the "-ed" is a grammatical ending. Other vowel sounds
should be kept (usualy). Software has to look at the TO to determine
whether or not the ending is grammatical, you can not do it solely
from the phonics.

You can solve this as follows:
if the TO ends in "-ed" then look the TO up twice in the CMU: once
with the ending and once without. If both forms are in the CMU then
the terminal "-ed" is (almost certainly) an grammatical ending
otherwise it is not. If it *is* an ending then and only then remove
any indefinite vowel sound before the terminal D (ie replace AH D with D)

Or as I said before in a general way applicable to all endings:
For grammatical endings, it is reasonable to do morphemic endings
programmatically with a trivial algorithm by querying the data for the
entry with the ending and then again without, if both entries exist
the difference is probably a suffix.
eg: is the -ing in "jumping" a suffix? it is if you can find "jump" in
the cmu.
eg: is the -ing in "thing" a suffix? it is not because there is no
entry for "th"



> > "loaded" will become Low-Owe-Day-Day.

Double Day is correct on occasion as is double Zoo.
